content: hello craft traveler welcome to my spaceship of the imagination now this is
part two of our hive nest videos so if you haven't seen part one make sure you
go back and watch that one first and in this video we're going to finish up the
hog nests and show you how creepy they can be so let's go to the table and
finish those up you
I'm going to start with a nice thick stock of card stock and I've got my
dried alien piece and I'm going to I glued it to the card stock with the
small glue gun and I'm pulling out going around the edge and pulling out some
glue to blend it into the base so there we go there's what it looks like I'm
going to cut this out and the next thing is to add some more detail usually I
like to add a second layer of detail if you try to add too much glue at one time
it'll just muddy the details so here's my one that's a wall section so I'm
doing in the edge of the card stock it's supposed to go up against the edge of a
wall so similar technique just go around the edge now cut that out and do some
more detailing don't be afraid to actually go up on the piece to blend it
in all right so here's one of my pieces
I've flat I've painted them flat black I'm going to use a burnt umber - I'll
wash this piece bring out all the detail there we are so we'll let that wash dry
now that it's dry I'm going to use a metallic black and go over the surface
like a dry brush technique and that'll kind of bring out the details and give
it this really creepy beetle look beetle shell look now for the main hive nests
it has sack so I want wanted to kind of paint them like the eggs I did my egg
video so I'm using the similar green or the same green it'll wash those a little
more green now we'll let those dry before you move
to the next step here we are I have a burnt sienna I'm gonna wash the egg sex
or the sex nest sex with those to bring out some more detail of the sax
I'm gonna use a wash of black to bring out the some more details and to cover
up some of the the bleed that I got from the washing of the sacs
I don't use this a water-based poly acrylic to get a nice sheen on these
nests so here they are they're all dried and I'm painted on now be careful when
you apply this you don't want to put too much or it'll mud it'll uh
muddy up it won't be clear so make sure you don't put too much at once I'm
trying to get all the details there here's the main nest and I'll do the
same thing I'll just paint it up make sure making sure I get in all the cracks
and crevices see I have a board there to catch any any glass I don't get on the
piece watch yourself sergeant don't touch anything
what is this stuff captain I don't know some kind of alien resin they seemed
even making some kind of nests this must be the home nest we must destroy it we
must destroy the entire facility so here we go here's a the one that branches off
I think that really looks good look how that the color changes when you move it
through the light I think that's really really cool and here's the main nest
with the sax I think those came out great and yeah look at that color it's
just really cool and here's one we did that fits up
against the wall so I made a flat edge so it could just slide right against the

holes in it and I think those came out really cool I think they really look
like alien nests
